And now I've got you on. A couple of things we're going to talk about. The first thing really

world championship this weekend in Las Vegas. How are you reflecting on this season for Max?
It's been a very unusual season because I think at the start of the year, if you look at the kind
of four wins from five at the start of the year and arguably in Australia, if you hadn't
have had his car failure, you probably would have won that as well. And we were looking like it's
going to be another 2023. He might even win every single race. And then the the form really did
dip down throughout the season. McLaren obviously took that massively forward in Miami and looked like
they had a better car definitely since Miami. But as we got into the middle part of the season,
and particularly after the summer break, Red Bull were really on the back foot. And I mean, Max's
form of finishing races for fifth, second, sixth was just so unusual for him because we'd,
even when he didn't have a championship winning car, he was still winning. He hadn't gone, I think
it was since 2020 or something that he'd gone without winning a race for 10 races, which a lot of
other drivers would absolutely take. But Max is stuff and it's unusual for him to go that long. But
I think it was very much a strange title fight where he kind of built that lead at the start. And then
it always looked like McLaren could get there, but they never quite got there. And then obviously
Brazil with how that completely flipped and going from looking like it was going to be a massive
shift towards McLaren and Lando Norris. And instead went completely opposite way where arguably he
could not even turn up for the last three races. And he might still win the championship. How far
gone it is now he only needs a handful of points to do it. And but it still is a very impressive
campaign. But I think couldn't be any more different to the one that he had last year where he just
dominated throughout the whole season because absolutely wasn't the case this year.
I was kind of going to ask you as well. Is it in a weird way? Is it his cleanest and most convincing
season to date in terms of the win? Because I guess all of them before he's 2021, obviously we
know what happened there. Then he's had this hugely dominant car, which let's be honest, no other

the what he's done on track. He has won it fair and square. Would you agree?
Yes, it's funny how it's panned out that I think even in 2023, which I think is unfair, but it's
stored it. You had exactly the same narrative with Lewis Hamilton when he was dominating a Michael
Schumacher. There's this thing in Formula One where people like to dismiss these drivers because

him to have almost a completely different season this year, where I think at times,

I mean, how impressed have you been with his sort of laser winning mentality focus on getting the job
done? Yeah, I think the best champions kind of put those difficult races behind them. I mean,
we can't shy away from the fact that maybe, you know, Hungary was not one of his finest races,
for example, or I think Azerbaijan, but it's only a handful of races really where
he's not delivered what the car could and is obviously completely trans his teammate this year
who's struggling massively. And I think the most impressive thing, and this is the case for all
great champions is that they can take all that negativity and when they're on the back for
